AnalystsTest.Text:
2/27/2015 5:08:37 PM
Our dependence on computers has increased tremendously. Right from running a school to a railway system or an aeroplane, we are depepndent on computers. Do you think, our lives are going to become more dependent on computers as technology advances? Is this dependence good for our overall development? Give reason.

YES, I THINK OUR LIVES ARE GOING TO BECOME MORE DEPENDENT ON COMPUTERS AS TECHNOLOGY ADVANCES AND YES THIS DEPENDENCE IS GOOD FOR THE OVERALL DEVELOPMENT,BECAUSE WE NEED TO CHANGE ALONG WITH THE CHANGES IN THE ENVIRONMENT, AS CHANGE IS STABLE AND CONSTANT.THERE IS A RAPID DEVELOPMENT IN THE INCREASE OF THE TECHNOLGY.INCREASE IN THE TECHNOLOGY GAVE RISE TO INCREASE IN THE TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES,AS A RESULT WE ARE SEEING MANY CHANGES IN OUR SOCIETY,COUNTRY AND THE WORLD AS A WHOLE.COMPUTER IS AN EXAMPLE FOR THE TECHNOLOGICL ADVANCE.IN SIMPLER WE CAN SAY THAT,COMPUTER IS AN OUTPUT OF THE TECHNOLOGY.HERE COMES THE IMPORTANCE OF TECHNOLOGY.

WHAT IS TECHNOLGY? TECHNOLOGY IS A GREEK WORD DERIVED FROM THE WORD "TECNIK" WHICH WERE USED BY JAPANESE,WHICH LATER CHANGED INTO THE WORD CALLED "TECHNOLOGY".TECHNOLOGY CAN BE DEFINED AS AN-"APPLICATION OF KNOWLEDGE IN PARTICULAR AREA".WITH THE HELP OF TECHNOLOGY MAN COULD ABLE TO COME OUT WITH MANY NEW THINGS, INNOVATIVE IDEAS AND NEW PRODUCTS.THE TREND HAS STARTED RIGHT FROM THE INVENTION OF FIRE,WHEEL ETC,.LATER THE INVENTION OF PRINTING PRESS,TELECOMMUNICATION,COMPUTERS,INTERNET HAS COME INTO THE EXISTENCE.

INTRODUCTION OF THE COMPUTER HAVE CHANGED THE LIFE STYLE OF A HUMAN BEING.COMPUTERS HAVE SOLVED THE PROBLEM OF THE COMPLEX TASKS INTO MUCH SIMPLER TASKS.EARLIER IT WAS USED TO PERFORM THE CALCULATIONS QUICKLY AND EASILY.APART FROM CALCULATIONS,IT IS VERY MUCH USEFULL FOR STORING THE DATA IN THE FORM OF THE DOCUMENTS.WITH THE HELP OF THE INTERNET EVERY INIVIDUALS ARE PERFORMING MULTIPLE TASKS.AN INDIVIDUAL GATHERS LOTS OF INFORMATION FROM ROUND THE WORLD BY JUST SITTING BEFORE THE COMPUTER.AN INDIVIDUAL GETS ACCEESS TO EVERY PART OF THE WORLD WITH THE HELP OF COMPUTER.

NOW A DAYS,AN INDIVIDUAL IS MORE DEPENDENT ON COMPUTER.BECAUSE,THEY PERFORM ALL THE TRANSACTIONS VERY QUICKLY AND EASILY AND CAN COMMUNICATE WITH EVRY OTHER PART OF THE WORLD.OUR EVERYDAY ACTIVITIES BEGINS WITH THE TECHNOLOGY IN PARTICULAR WITH THE COMPUTERS.WITH THE HELP OF COMPUTERS ORGANISATIONS COULD PERFORM THEIR BUSINESS ACTIVITIES ONLINE AND MAKE ONLINE TRANSACTIONS,CONDUCT ONLINE MEETINGS THROUGH VIDEO CONFERENCE,RIGHT FROM THEIR EXISTING LOCATIONS.

THE COMPUTERS ARE VERY MUCH USED IN SCHOOLS FOR EDUCATION,USED IN THE FIRMS TO MAKE TRANSACTIONS AND HIGHLY USED IN TRANSPORTATION LIKE RAILWAYS,AIRWAYS,ROADWAYS FOR MAKING ONLINE RESERVATIONS.THIS MADE INCREASE IN THE PURCHASES OF THE COMPUTERS WHICH MADE THE HUMANS TO BECOME MORE DEPENDENT ON COMPUTERS.


File Name:WorldAutoIndustryOutlookJune2013
Start editing from here.

The auto industry is highly concentrated. The top 10 global automakers account for roughly 80% of the worldwide production and nearly 90% of total vehicles sold in the U.S.

Toyota recaptured the sales crown from General Motors by selling 9.75 million vehicles globally in 2012, which exceeded GM`s sales of 9.29 million vehicles. Germany`s Volkswagen AG ( VLKAY ) came third with sales of 9.07 million vehicles for the year.

Developing the supplier networks remains one of the greatest challenges due to the cost and demand factors in shifting their production facilities to new regions,while existing suppliers lack in the financial strength to expand capac ity in the new markets.On the other hand, auto parts suppliers are sensitive to technology transfers to local third parties, which can give rise to low-cost competitors.

High dependence on automakers makes the auto market suppliers vulnerable to several maladies, primarily pricing pressure and production cuts. Pricing pressure from automakers constricts parts suppliers` margins and production cuts by automakers driven by frequent market adjustments negatively affect their operations.

 Future of Green Cars Looks Bleak

Rising fuel prices and global warming have turned attention to the auto industry that either rely less on traditional fossil fuels or use cheaper renewable sources of energy.Despite the U.S. Government`s continued effort to promote "green" alternatives such as fuel-efficient electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid vehicles,in the near future.Globally, the hybrid market is ruled by Toyota (which includes the Prius) and Honda (includes Civic and Insight hybrids). U.S. is the largest hybrid car market in the world with sales accounting for 60%-70% of global hybrid sales.The other automakers such as Ford, General Motors and Nissan are also aggressively pursuing a plan to push hybrid sales by introducing some of the well-recognized "green" cars include the Ford Focus, GM Volt, Nissan Leaf and Daimler AG`s ( DDAIF ) smart USA micro EV.

However, the industry has witnessed some notable adverse developments in the drive for green technology. In January 2013, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) backed off President Barack Obama`s stated goal of putting 1 million electric cars on the road by 2015 due to weaker than expected demand for plug-ins/EVs.According to Hybridcars.com, plug-in/EV sales constituted a meager 3.3% of the overall sales in the U.S. in 2012 and the weak demand for plug-ins/EVs has led some lithium-ion battery makers file for bankruptcy protection. They include MA-based A123 Systems Inc. and NY-based EnerDel, despite both being DOE grant recipients (A123 - $249.1 million; EnerDel - $118.5 million). It also led another DOE grant recipient (in fact, the third largest with $161.0 million), Dow Kokam, to be written down by chemical behemoth Dow Chemical ( DOW ), who jointly operated the entity with TK Advanced Battery LLC since 2009. 




#################--Don`t Delete below content#################

World Auto Industry Outlook - June 2013

The auto industry is highly concentrated. The top 10 global automakers account for roughly 80% of the worldwide production and nearly 90% of total vehicles sold in the U.S.

Toyota recaptured the sales crown from General Motors by selling 9.75 million vehicles globally in 2012, which exceeded GM`s sales of 9.29 million vehicles. Germany`s Volkswagen AG ( VLKAY ) came third with sales of 9.07 million vehicles for the year.

Although automakers continue to focus on shifting their production facilities to new regions driven by cost and demand factors, developing the supplier networks remains one of their greatest challenges. Existing suppliers to automakers often lack the financial strength to expand capacity in new markets. On the other hand, auto parts suppliers are sensitive to technology transfers to local third parties, which can give rise to low-cost competitors.

High dependence on automakers makes the auto market suppliers vulnerable to several maladies, primarily pricing pressure and production cuts. Pricing pressure from automakers constricts parts suppliers` margins. On the other hand, production cuts by automakers driven by frequent market adjustments negatively affect their operations.

Future of Green Cars Looks Bleak

Rising fuel prices and global warming have turned attention to the auto industry that either rely less on traditional fossil fuels or use cheaper renewable sources of energy. Despite the U.S. Government`s continued effort to promote "green" alternatives such as fuel-efficient electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid vehicles, things look bleak, at least in the near future. Globally, the hybrid market is ruled by Toyota (which includes the Prius) and Honda (includes Civic and Insight hybrids). Meanwhile, other automakers such as Ford, General Motors and Nissan are also aggressively pursuing a plan to push hybrid sales. Some of the well-recognized "green" cars include the Ford Focus, GM Volt, Nissan Leaf and Daimler AG`s ( DDAIF ) smart USA micro EV. U.S. is the largest hybrid car market in the world with sales accounting for 60%-70% of global hybrid sales.

However, the industry has witnessed some notable adverse developments in the drive for green technology. In January 2013, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) backed off President Barack Obama`s stated goal of putting 1 million electric cars on the road by 2015 due to weaker than expected demand for plug-ins/EVs. According to Hybridcars.com, plug-in/EV sales constituted a meager 3.3% of the overall sales in the U.S. in 2012. The weak demand for plug-ins/EVs has led some lithium-ion battery makers file for bankruptcy protection in 2012. They include MA-based A123 Systems Inc. and NY-based EnerDel, despite both being DOE grant recipients (A123 - $249.1 million; EnerDel - $118.5 million). It also led another DOE grant recipient (in fact, the third largest with $161.0 million), Dow Kokam, to be written down by chemical behemoth Dow Chemical ( DOW ), who jointly operated the entity with TK Advanced Battery LLC since 2009.
